sen.j: 金剛院（こんごういん）は京都府舞鶴市にある真言宗東寺派の寺院。
sen.e: Kongo-in Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Toji branch of the Shingon Sect located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kongo-in Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Toji branch of the Shingon Sect located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kongo-in Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Toji school of the Shingon Sect located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号は鹿原山、寺号は慈恩寺。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Kaharasan' and its title is 'Jion-ji'.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Kaharasan' and its title is 'Jion-ji'.
Its honorific mountain prefix is 'Mt. Kahara' and its title is 'Jion-ji.'
sen.cmt: 鹿原山→Mt. Kaharaに修正、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.e: The principal image is Namikiri Fudomyoo
The principal image is Namikiri Fudomyoo
The principal image is Namikiri Fudomyoo

sen.j: 三島由紀夫の小説「金閣寺」の舞台である。
sen.e: The temple is the setting for Yukio MISHIMA's novel entitled 'Kinkaku-ji' (The Temple of the Golden Pavilion).
The temple is the setting for Yukio MISHIMA's novel entitled 'Kinkaku-ji' (The Temple of the Golden Pavilion).
The temple is the setting for Yukio MISHIMA's novel entitled 'Kinkaku-ji' (The Temple of the Golden Pavilion).

sen.j: 秋には、江戸時代に細川幽斎（藤孝）が鶴亀の庭とともに植樹された楓が有名で多くの参拝がある。
sen.e: The maple trees that Yusai (Fujitaka) HOSOKAWA planted along with the Tsurukame-no-Niwa (Crane and Turtle Garden) in the Edo period are particularly famous and receive many visitors in autumn.
The maple trees that Yusai (Fujitaka) HOSOKAWA planted along with the Tsurukame-no-Niwa (Crane and Turtle Garden) in the Edo period are particularly famous and receive many visitors in autumn.
The maple trees that Yusai (Fujitaka) HOSOKAWA planted along with the Tsurukame no Niwa (Crane and Turtle Garden) in the Edo period are particularly famous and receive many visitors in autumn.

sen.j: 寺伝では、天長6年（829年）、高岳親王（たかおかしんのう、799 - 865）が創建したという。
sen.e: According to temple legend, it was founded in the year 829 by Imperial Prince Takaoka (799-865).
According to temple legend, it was founded in the year 829 by Imperial Prince Takaoka (799-865).
According to temple legend, it was founded in the year 829 by Imperial Prince Takaoka (799-865).

sen.j: 高岳親王は平城天皇第3皇子で、嵯峨天皇の皇太子となったが、薬子の変に連座して皇太子位を廃された。
sen.e: Prince Takaoka was the third Prince of Emperor Heijo and became the crown prince of Emperor Saga but lost his status after being implicated in the Kusuko Incident.
Prince Takaoka was the third Prince of Emperor Heijo and became the crown prince of Emperor Saga but lost his status after being implicated in the Kusuko Incident.
Imperial Prince Takaoka was the third Prince of Emperor Heijo and became the crown prince of Emperor Saga but lost his status after being implicated in the Kusuko Incident.

sen.j: 親王は後に空海の弟子となり、真如法親王とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: The prince later became the disciple of Kukai and became known as Shinnyo Hoshinno ('Hoshinno' refers to a prince who has entered the Buddhist priesthood).
The prince later became a disciple of Kukai and became known as Shinnyo Hoshinno ('Hoshinno' refers to a prince who has entered the Buddhist priesthood).
The prince later became a disciple of Kukai and became known as Cloistered Imperial Prince Shinnyo.
sen.cmt: 法親王の表記を修正、および補足を削除

sen.j: 室町時代には三重塔が再建された。
sen.e: The three-storey pagoda was reconstructed during the Muromachi period.
The three-storey pagoda was reconstructed during the Muromachi period.
The three-storey pagoda was reconstructed during the Muromachi period.

tit.cmt: 通例複数形のため、Precinctsとしました。

sen.cmt: 他の表記と合わせ文頭の頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.e: a tomb of Imperial Prince Takaoka
a tomb of Imperial Prince Takaoka
A tomb of Imperial Prince Takaoka
sen.cmt: 他の表記と合わせ文頭の頭文字を大文字に変更
○○坂→統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 絹本着色薬師十二神将像
sen.e: Color on silk image of Yakushi Nyorai and his twelve divine generals
Color on silk image of Yakushi Nyorai and his twelve divine generals
Color painting on silk image of Yakushi Nyorai and his twelve divine generals

sen.j: 木造執金剛神立像（快慶作）

sen.j: 〒625-0014 京都府舞鶴市鹿原595（金剛院京都府歴史的自然環境保全地域）
sen.e: 595 Kahara, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture 625-0014 (Kongo-in Temple Kyoto City Historic Nature Conservation Area)
595 Kahara, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture 625-0014 (Kongo-in Temple Kyoto City Historic Nature Conservation Area)
595 Kahara, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture 625-0014 (Kongo-in Temple Kyoto Prefectural Historic Nature Conservation Area)

sen.j: 毎月28日午前8時 - 不動講
sen.e: 8pm on 28th of every month: Dharma lecture on the merits of Fudo
8pm on 28th of every month: Dharma lecture on the merits of Fudo
8am on 28th of every month: Dharma lecture on the merits of Fudo
sen.cmt: 8pm→8amに修正 (28thに合わせスペルアウトせず)

sen.j: 舞鶴若狭自動車道舞鶴東インターチェンジから北東へ約5km
sen.e: Approximately 5km northeast of the Maizuru-Wakasa Expressway's Maizuru-higashi Interchange.
Approximately 5km northeast of the Maizuru-Wakasa Expressway's Maizuru-higashi Interchange.
Approximately five kilometers northeast of the Maizuru-Wakasa Expressway's Maizuru-higashi Interchange.
sen.cmt: 5km→five kilometers、Expressway’sのアポストロフィーを半角に修正

sen.j: 西日本旅客鉄道舞鶴線東舞鶴駅下車、京都交通 (舞鶴)高浜白鳥線で約16分、鹿原（かわら）停留所下車で徒歩5分
sen.e: Take the West Japan Railway Company Maizuru Line to Higashi-Maizuru Station, from here take the Kyoto Kotsu Bus (Maizuru) Takahama-Shiratori route for 16 minutes to the Kawara Bus Stop and walk for 5 minutes.

Take the West Japan Railway Company Maizuru Line to Higashi-Maizuru Station, from here take the Kyoto Kotsu Bus (Maizuru) Takahama-Shiratori route for 16 minutes to the Kawara Bus Stop and walk for 5 minutes.

Take the West Japan Railway Maizuru Line to Higashi-Maizuru Station, from here take the Kyoto Kotsu Bus (Maizuru) Takahama-Shiratori route for 16 minutes to the Kawara Bus Stop and walk for 5 minutes.

sen.j: 金剛院を含む地域一円は、平安時代後期には「志楽庄」と呼ばれた地域で、武士 平忠盛の子の平清盛が支配したこともある地域である。
sen.e: In the latter part of the Heian period, the entire area in which Kongo-in Temple is situated was known as 'Shiraku-no-Sho' and was ruled by TAIRA no Kiyomori, son of the Samurai TAIRA no Tadamori.
In the latter part of the Heian period, the entire area in which Kongo-in Temple is situated was known as 'Shiraku-no-Sho' and was ruled by TAIRA no Kiyomori, son of the Samurai TAIRA no Tadamori.
In the latter part of the Heian period, the entire area in which Kongo-in Temple is situated was known as 'Shiraku no Sho' and was ruled by TAIRA no Kiyomori, son of the Samurai TAIRA no Tadamori.
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとり、Shiraku no Shoとしました。

sen.j: この、金剛院の参道の入り口付近にそびえる、高さ約25メートルの巨大な木は「奉行杉」と呼ばれ、同院の造営奉行を命じられた忠盛が植えたとの言い伝えがあるものである。
sen.e: The large approximately 25 meter tall tree that rises up from near the entrance to the temple approach is known as 'Bugyosugi' and is said to have been planted by TAIRA No Kiyomori, who was appointed 'Zoei Buguyo' (Temple Administrator).

The large approximately 25 meter tall tree that rises up from near the entrance to the temple approach is known as 'Bugyosugi' and is said to have been planted by TAIRA No Kiyomori, who was appointed 'Zoei Buguyo' (Temple Administrator).

The large approximately 25 meter tall tree that rises up from near the entrance to the temple approach is known as 'Bugyosugi' and is said to have been planted by TAIRA No Kiyomori, who was appointed 'Zoei Bugyo' (Temple Administrator).
